author: tbsn.
content: What's the most recent state of eip1559? Does it look like all of the BASEFEE will be burned or will some part of it go somewhere?

author: pipermerriam
content: Has there been talk about using it to subsidize protocol development? I know it is contentious but it also feels like the way to have sustainable funding. I am  of course not objective on this subject and have my own conflict of interests since my job falls into the category of jobs that could be funded by such a mechanism.

author: pipermerriam
content: If so, is there anywhere I could read up on the conversation this far?

author: kiwi.eth
content: I think the main thing against allocating the fees instead of burning them is, who would control where the fees go and how they're distributed? It would seem a lot like a dev tax similar to zcash

author: kiwi.eth
content: And burning it removes any possible incentives for fee manipulation, also creates an interesting economic setup combined with PoS

author: kiwi.eth
content: I think there could be more interesting ways of funding if we'd like to make it more protocol level, fees going to a controlled party just seems... weird.

author: sky.cactus
content: The hard part of subsidizing protocol development is deciding who gets paid, not where the money comes from.  ðŸ˜¢

author: kiwi.eth
content: Vitalik brought up this a while back <https://cointelegraph.com/news/vitalik-buterin-proposes-that-wallets-charge-gas-fee-for-transactions> to add a small 1 gwei per TX that goes towards the node implementers

author: sky.cactus
content: If 2718 goes through we could create a new transaction type where the sender sends ETH to an address that is separate from the `to` field.

author: sky.cactus
content: Then nodes could be configured to only forward transactions coming in to their RPC that include a sufficient fee.
